awd_titl_txt: CCRI: Planning: Collaborative Research: Planning to Develop a Low-Power Computer Vision Platform to Enhance Research in Computing Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is a planning grant to investigate how to develop a research infrastructure for investigating energy-efficient computer vision. Computer vision is a set of technologies for understanding image or video. These technologies are essential in many applications, such as autonomous vehicles and airport security. Some vision systems need to be energy-efficient because they use batteries, for example, drones and mobile phones. This infrastructure is planned to be available for researchers to experiment and evaluate their solutions. The evaluation includes the success rates of identifying different types of objects, the speed, and the energy consumption. The infrastructure has three major components: (1) video taken by drones, (2) vision system analyzing the data, (3) power meter.  It will be designed for a wide range of vision problems.  It will also include a referee system which automates the entire evaluation process.  

There are many beneficial applications for low-power computer vision, for example, lightweight cameras that may provide safety for the vision impaired, wearable cameras that may improve factory safety or perform inventory analysis, and cameras for observing wildlife. The planning grant is to assess the needs of such an infrastructure for academia and industry. This team will actively engage the research community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project builds the research infrastructure for low-power computer vision. Computer vision is the technology using computers to recognize visual information (images or videos). Computer vision requires heavy computation and thus usually runs on fast computers with graphics processing units (GPUs). Many applications, however, need to run computer vision on mobile computers, such as phones and UAV (unmanned aerial vehicles, also called drones). These mobile systems rely on batteries and computer vision must be efficient (i.e., low-power).

This project creates the tools for researchers to evaluate their low-power computer vision solutions. The tools are used in two international competitions: 2021 Low-Power Computer Vision Challenge (LPCVC) and 2022 Autonomous UAV Chase Challenge (AUAVC).

The 2021 LPCVC requires that participants' solutions tracks moving objects in videos captured by a UAV. The videos are people passing balls. The people, the balls, and the UAV may move. The purpose is to determine which person hold the ball. The competition was held in August 2021; 53 teams submitted 366 solutions.The winning solutions were presented in the 2022 International Conference of Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition (CVPR) and 2022 International Conference for Artificial Intelligence Circuits and Systems (AICAS).

The 2022 AUAVC requires that the solutions follow a ground rover in an environment filled with obstacles, including one tunnel. The UAV has to follow the rover at one meter distance, without colliding with any obstacle. Seven teams from China, Greece, India, Italy, Poland, Russia, South Korea and the United States submitted their solutions to be evaluated in a simulator. The top three teams submitted their solutions to be tested the PX4 UAV and launched inside the 20,000-square-foot Purdue UAS Research and Test Facility (PURT).

A book was published on the topic of "Low-Power Computer Vision: Improve the Efficiency of Artificial Intelligence",

ISBN 9780367744700, February, 2022 by Chapman and Hall/CRC.
